body_html:
I think there’s a bug in your code. The following lines:

def main(_):
    dataset = tensorflow.contrib.data.TFRecordDataset("path")
    dataset.map(parse_function)
    dataset.batch(64)

...should be changed to:

def main(_):
    dataset = tensorflow.contrib.data.TFRecordDataset("path")
    dataset = dataset.map(parse_function)
    dataset = dataset.batch(64)

The high-level point is that calling methods on a Dataset does not modify an existing object; instead it returns a new Dataset, so you must assign the returned value to a Python variable (or chain it with other methods that are eventually assigned to a Python variable).

    dataset = dataset.batch(64)
The high-level point is that calling methods on a Dataset does not modify an existing object; instead it returns a new Dataset, so you must assign the returned value to a Python variable (or chain it with other methods that are eventually assigned to a Python variable).
body:
I think there’s a bug in your code. The following lines:

```python
def main(_):
    dataset = tensorflow.contrib.data.TFRecordDataset("path")
    dataset.map(parse_function)
    dataset.batch(64)
```

...should be changed to:

```python
def main(_):
    dataset = tensorflow.contrib.data.TFRecordDataset("path")
    dataset = dataset.map(parse_function)
    dataset = dataset.batch(64)
```

The high-level point is that calling methods on a `Dataset` does not modify an existing object; instead it returns a new `Dataset`, so you must assign the returned value to a Python variable (or chain it with other methods that are eventually assigned to a Python variable).
